body: But who told you "The Bible = inspired word of God"? Are you not relying on mankind for that assumption? Is it not because a church or religious institution told you so? Do you know who compiled and canonized your Bible? Do you know who translated your Bible? Do you know the hundreds of thousands of scribes who copied the texts we have in our possession? Did you know there are up to 5,000 meaningful variants in the new testament alone? And that's just in the few manuscripts we have, the earliest texts would have been the most wild (unfortunately the church destroyed them to promote their version). Are you aware of the attacks on fake scriptures and pious forgeries in both the new and old testaments? Ever notice how there's a clear gradual progression from outlandish sociopathic paganism to agape faith living from the oldest parts of the bible to the newer ones? What do you think that means? And behold, the prophets confirmed that the former was put there by the lying pens of scribes. Religious institutions have always been by man, for man, exhorting the gullible masses for power and money. The bible is quite convenient for pharisees and televangelists, because it says just about everything, so they can just decide what they want people to think and cherry pick the parts of the bible that support it. And while everyone is listening to their favorite megachurch pastor and quoting the Pauline corpus out of context or from forgeries, no one bothers to pick up Matthew, Mark, Luke, or John and notice the parallels between their greedy church organization and the leaders of the pharisees and sadducees.

body: I'd recommend an interlinear, bonus points if it shows textual variants. The reason I say this is because all translations are biased towards the views of the translator, sometimes even blatantly. Another minor reason is that bible translations tend to translate into excessively formal language and use religious terms for what was originally everyday words, making everything extremely confusing to the point where the original is easier to read. Do not buy a bible, that is supporting the greedy religious organizations. Use free websites, there are a lot of them.

body:
Unfortunately, we don't have any of the autographs. The church probably burned them along with all the other texts that didn't conform to their version. But we do have the bulk of truth remaining, just alongside forgeries. We know the nature of God and the two or one commandments (depending on how you look at it), and we know about atonement and the resurrection and such and such. But as with anything, you have to use discernment according to those core pillars of faith. However, almost every time I come across a suspicious passage in the bible, there are significant signs of it being a later addition. It's not good to put full trust in the writers anyway; even though they were good people, they were not God, and there's a chance they were wrong about something. These days people practically treat them as if they are more divine than Jesus himself, especially Paul but also Peter, David, Moses, etc (which in my opinion shows they see them as mythological figures and not real historical people).

By "progression from sociopathic paganism to agape faith" I meant that in the most recent texts, the new testament, you have a few suspicious passages in the authentic books, maybe a fake chapter or two, etc, but it's mostly in agreement with the fundamental principles it lays out. However in the old testament, in the oldest books you have all kinds of completely outlandish laws and stories. "God" says to make animal sacrifices because of the "pleasing aroma" and commands genocide and slaughtering of children. "Moses" condones sex slavery and pedophilia, says to burn people at the stake, and that eunuchs, blind people, or anyone with any kind of disability whatsoever is an abomination and should go kill themselves. The true parts may actually be in the minority here. But the later you go, the less of this there is, and the latter, true theme becomes more prevalent. There are less contradictions and the brutality and cruelty disappears. The prophets begin to denounce these corruptions, with Jeremiah addressing the situation directly. By the time you get to the new testament it's just a few cringey passages here and there with the rest being pure. The reason for this is that the later texts are more recent, and the older ones have had more time to be corrupted by scribes.

post.body:
Currently most successful people are men. So are the least. The current consensus is that the average intelligence for both sexes is the same, but males are more variable than females.

I call that bull. I think the entire intelligence curve for females is simply shifted to the right of males. In every single hard class at high school and university level, there are far more boys but the handful of girls are always at the top of the class, easily solving problems that stump the hell out of the boys. It's the same at any non-blue-collar workplace, there are more male employees overall but the female minority does a better job, is more productive, and comes up with more ideas. All across the board it's been shown that girls are substantially better learners than boys, and have sharper and more active minds. Girls also have a *significant* advantage in the arts, languages, music, humanities, even just simple functions like memory and emotion. While still having a slight advantage even in "male" subjects like STEM. Pretty much anything involving designing or creating, even simple outside the box thinking, females are naturally going to be way better. Males commit suicide 3.5x more despite supposedly having less depression (I suspect it's actually because depression is biologically hardwired into males so is rarely taken seriously for them, in fact "whining" about it is usually punished).

It's not just stereotypes and observational evidence though. Brain scans back this up too. Female brains are typically a bit smaller, but so was Einstein's. Female brains have denser neurons that more than make up for it, and their hippocampus and cortices are all larger and wired much more efficiently than in males, which correlates to higher cognitive ability. Not only that, but it's been shown that males pretty much exclusively use the left side of their brain (logical, stoic, rational, logical, and blunt) while females are capable of using both sides. This is why men are usually so uncreative, unemotional (except for anger), unartistic, unsympathetic, and lack even the most basic intuition and feeling. Pretty much the only thing males excel at in the mental realm is spatial awareness. And even then, only in the real physical world; females are still usually superior at crafting, designing, and drawing shapes and 3d perspectives. This also makes biological sense. Think back to ancient times, when male was the more "disposable" sex that was constantly sent into risky and brutal situations, fighting, mating, and laboring, while the females engaged more in homemaking, childrearing, and organizing society. You don't need much of a brain to do the former, and with so many resources devoted to it, males lose a lot of other capabilities. Men are pretty much smarter as children than they are as adults! Why do you think Homer Simpson is so familiar? This explains some other things too, like why men die younger and feel pain worse despite having to endure more painful situations.

So why are some men still more successful and have higher IQs? My theory is societal expectations. From the moment they enter school, boys MUST succeed, do what they're told, and do it *extremely* well or there will be consequences. Girls are usually given a lot more slack. Boys are expected to have careers and become independent, whereas girls are allowed to leech off of them their whole lives, and allowed to run to someone else crying for help with every tiny thing that doesn't go their way. So what happens is that only the ambitious girls end up cultivating their skills. And when they do, the results are amazing. But obviously the people who actually *want* to pursue things instead of being lazy are the minority of the population. If you pick out 10 geniuses, chances are 9 of them will be boys but the one girl will be smarter than half of them combined. She will usually be multi-talented, easy to work with, have a lot of ideas, well-rounded and brilliant. Top IQs reflect this, in which they are almost all males but the #1 spot goes to a female. If most females would put down the makeup and snapchat and become interested in something actually productive like the males are made to do, I think their intelligence would improve quite drastically. But we instead encourage that hyper "girly" behavior which doesn't accomplish anything except make it even harder for the sexes to understand each other than it already would be. Boys are far too neglected and girls are way too coddled. It doesn't make any sense to have lower expectations for the ones with higher potential. I think there needs to be a serious shift in raising girls to become productive persons rather than docile crybabies. They'd be happier and have more fun that way too.

post.body: I'm curious about some of you think of this story. Personally I think it's fake, as it's only referenced at the beginning of Matthew and Luke, the latter clearly being a later addition to the original Luke. Nowhere else do any of the writers show any indication of knowing about a virgin birth, including in the rest of Matthew and Luke. Additionally, some of the oldest manuscripts of Matthew read "Joseph begat Jesus" and many current references to Joseph are "Jesus's father" in the oldest manuscripts. The genealogy in Matthew makes no sense if Mary conceived as a virgin, as it shows Joseph's line of descent, not Mary's, and the whole point is to show how Jesus came from the Davidic line. I have a theory however about why this story was added: the faithless church fathers, instead of believing because it is self-evident, either newly interpreted Isaiah 7:14 as messianic, or it was actually put there by Matthew, but the church fathers, due to a mistranslation in the LXX, thought it meant virgin when it was actually young woman (the same word is used for both). Either way, they lacked faith and only cared about creating a religious system to control people, and authored this story to "prove" it right. Ironically, the original Hebrew prophecy is only correct if Joseph is Jesus's (biological) father. It's also possible that they wanted to introduce elements of pagan legends, though harmless ones in this case (unless you take it to the extreme of worshiping Mary).

body: I hate to break it to you, but God's goal isn't to make you happy either. Well it is, but for now that is not the priority. This is a broken world and it's difficult to realize just how far it's fallen without trials. And I mean *endless* trials. This is not your home, you are not meant to be happy here. Much of this world is left up to chance, and some people get lucky and can live a comfortable but annoying life, and a select few have a shot at being happy, but otherwise it's a grim situation. And be warned, Satan often makes the lives of the faithful, especially new converts, utterly fall apart like Job's to try and break their faith.

body:
> Clearly? What makes it clear?

The 3rd chapter of Luke reads like the beginning of the story, and also introduces several things that had already been mentioned in the first two chapters, such as Herod and Zechariah. There is also a few concerning passages in the first two chapters, including:

* Not being procreative, even by physical infertility, is called a "disgrace" (Luke 1:25) even though the entire new testament praises celibacy, except for the pseudographia.

* John enjoys a near-equal status to Jesus (Luke 1:39-45, also implies that John was simply "born good", and keeps insisting that the two are blood related)

* The entire account of Luke 1-2 does not line up with Matthew at all. Luke 3 is also perfectly natural as it aligns with the beginning of Mark.

* Mary is given an elevated role in Luke 1

* Mary and Joseph travel for an ENTIRE DAY without noticing that their son is missing? (Luke 2:43-44)

* Luke 2:52 WHAT? Jesus *grew* in wisdom? Implying that he is not perfect! And he grew in favor with MAN? Doesn't sound anything like him but it *does* sound a lot like the epistles forged by the church fathers.

> I've heard it said, and am inclined to believe, that the legal line of descent was more important than the actual genetic line of descent. For example, if a married man died without children, his brother was responsible for giving seed to the wife, and the children of that wife would carry on the family name of the dead man, not the biological father.

You're correct that it doesn't and shouldn't matter. However, males are hardwired to first and foremost want to pass their genes on to another generation and continue their family legacy. This is why they have such high sex drives. It's also why they are obsessed with making sure that their children are really *their* children biologically, and also why an adoption just won't satisfy them as much and they love their biological children much more. It's a deep primal instinct that males have. So because of this, God made a promise to both Abraham and David that the messiah would be a descendant of them. And the whole point of the genealogy is to prove that this was fulfilled.

> Having said that, in the legal sense, do the genealogies not show Jesus as having been of the seed of David? I understand there is at least an apparent discrepancy in the two lines of descent, but they do serve to show him as descending from David, do they not?

No, because it shows Joseph's line of descent instead of Mary's. It also shows that unless there were conflicting records, one of them is just made up. As to which one, according to the church fathers they had been mistaken about their prior statements of Hebrew Matthew having no genealogy, and that it actually did contain one. However, the one in Luke interrupts the flow of the text, and there are several comments from the church fathers that some versions back then did not include it. Take that as you will.

> Is this not all pure conjecture? Where is there anything to back up anything you are saying?

That's why I called a theory.

> Why would it be hard to imagine God himself conceived Jesus in Mary? Doesn't it fit with everything else about the Messiah? That he shall be called "God with us"? Does Genesis itself not reference angels mating with women? So we know that it's possible for spirits to impregnate women (if you believe the bible), why couldn't God? Does this all boil down to what the word in Isaiah really was originally? Whether virgin or young maiden?

First of all, the old testament prophecies said the messiah would be the seed of David. Secondly, your explanation implies both that Mary and God *literally* had sex, which also implies immaculate conception, and also that Jesus was who he was because of who his biological parents were. You yourself stated that the spiritual inheritance is more important than the physical, so why does that suddenly not apply in this instance? Is God not supposed to be our father also, despite not being so biologically?

Clearly? What makes it clear?

The 3rd chapter of Luke reads like the beginning of the story, and also introduces several things that had already been mentioned in the first two chapters, such as Herod and Zechariah. There is also a few concerning passages in the first two chapters, including:

  • Not being procreative, even by physical infertility, is called a "disgrace" (Luke 1:25) even though the entire new testament praises celibacy, except for the pseudographia.

  • John enjoys a near-equal status to Jesus (Luke 1:39-45, also implies that John was simply "born good", and keeps insisting that the two are blood related)

  • The entire account of Luke 1-2 does not line up with Matthew at all. Luke 3 is also perfectly natural as it aligns with the beginning of Mark.

  • Mary is given an elevated role in Luke 1

  • Mary and Joseph travel for an ENTIRE DAY without noticing that their son is missing? (Luke 2:43-44)

  • Luke 2:52 WHAT? Jesus grew in wisdom? Implying that he is not perfect! And he grew in favor with MAN? Doesn't sound anything like him but it does sound a lot like the epistles forged by the church fathers.

I've heard it said, and am inclined to believe, that the legal line of descent was more important than the actual genetic line of descent. For example, if a married man died without children, his brother was responsible for giving seed to the wife, and the children of that wife would carry on the family name of the dead man, not the biological father.

You're correct that it doesn't and shouldn't matter. However, males are hardwired to first and foremost want to pass their genes on to another generation and continue their family legacy. This is why they have such high sex drives. It's also why they are obsessed with making sure that their children are really their children biologically, and also why an adoption just won't satisfy them as much and they love their biological children much more. It's a deep primal instinct that males have. So because of this, God made a promise to both Abraham and David that the messiah would be a descendant of them. And the whole point of the genealogy is to prove that this was fulfilled.

Having said that, in the legal sense, do the genealogies not show Jesus as having been of the seed of David? I understand there is at least an apparent discrepancy in the two lines of descent, but they do serve to show him as descending from David, do they not?

No, because it shows Joseph's line of descent instead of Mary's. It also shows that unless there were conflicting records, one of them is just made up. As to which one, according to the church fathers they had been mistaken about their prior statements of Hebrew Matthew having no genealogy, and that it actually did contain one. However, the one in Luke interrupts the flow of the text, and there are several comments from the church fathers that some versions back then did not include it. Take that as you will.

Is this not all pure conjecture? Where is there anything to back up anything you are saying?

That's why I called a theory.

Why would it be hard to imagine God himself conceived Jesus in Mary? Doesn't it fit with everything else about the Messiah? That he shall be called "God with us"? Does Genesis itself not reference angels mating with women? So we know that it's possible for spirits to impregnate women (if you believe the bible), why couldn't God? Does this all boil down to what the word in Isaiah really was originally? Whether virgin or young maiden?

First of all, the old testament prophecies said the messiah would be the seed of David. Secondly, your explanation implies both that Mary and God literally had sex, which also implies immaculate conception, and also that Jesus was who he was because of who his biological parents were. You yourself stated that the spiritual inheritance is more important than the physical, so why does that suddenly not apply in this instance? Is God not supposed to be our father also, despite not being so biologically?

>the latter clearly being a later addition to the original Luke

Clearly? What makes it clear? 

>The genealogy in Matthew makes no sense if Mary conceived as a virgin, as it shows Joseph's line of descent, not Mary's, and the whole point is to show how Jesus came from the Davidic line.

I've heard it said, and am inclined to believe, that the legal line of descent was more important than the actual genetic line of descent. For example, if a married man died without children, his brother was responsible for giving seed to the wife, and the children of that wife would carry on the family name of the dead man, not the biological father. 

Having said that, in the legal sense, do the genealogies not show Jesus as having been of the seed of David? I understand there is at least an *apparent* discrepancy in the two lines of descent, but they do serve to show him as descending from David, do they not?

>I have a theory however about why this story was added: the faithless church fathers, instead of believing because it is self-evident, either newly interpreted Isaiah 7:14 as messianic, or it was actually put there by Matthew, but the church fathers, due to a mistranslation in the LXX, thought it meant virgin when it was actually young woman (the same word is used for both). Either way, they lacked faith and only cared about creating a religious system to control people, and authored this story to "prove" it right. Ironically, the original Hebrew prophecy is only correct if Joseph is Jesus's (biological) father. It's also possible that they wanted to introduce elements of pagan legends, though harmless ones in this case (unless you take it to the extreme of worshiping Mary).

Is this not all pure conjecture? Where is there anything to back up anything you are saying?

Why would it be hard to imagine God himself conceived Jesus in Mary? Doesn't it fit with everything else about the Messiah? That he shall be called "God with us"? Does Genesis itself not reference angels mating with women? So we know that it's possible for spirits to impregnate women (if you believe the bible), why couldn't God? Does this all boil down to what the word in Isaiah really was originally? Whether virgin or young maiden?

body:
> John considered himself unworthy to loose the straps of Jesus' sandals

Yes...in chapter 3. But 1-2 elevates his status quite a bit.

> Where do you get the idea that John was born good?

Jesus and John interact in the womb when Mary and Elizabeth meet, or so we are told. This implies that John was inherently good and faithful since conception. It also repeatedly stresses John being a blood relative to Jesus, as if his goodness has to do with that.

Alright dude you're off base enough that I'm not going to take the time to respond to this whole thing, but i will be fair and of show you in one point how you are off base:

>John enjoys a near-equal status to Jesus (Luke 1:39-45, also implies that John was simply "born good", and keeps insisting that the two are blood related)

I don't see how any of this can be inferred at all, let alone from Luke 1:39-45. John did not enjoy near equal status to Jesus, John considered himself unworthy to loose the straps of Jesus' sandals. Jesus said John was the greatest among men, but still less than the least in the kingdom of heaven. Where do you get the idea that John was born good?

post.body: I'm curious about some of you think of this story. Personally I think it's fake, as it's only referenced at the beginning of Matthew and Luke, the latter clearly being a later addition to the original Luke. Nowhere else do any of the writers show any indication of knowing about a virgin birth, including in the rest of Matthew and Luke. Additionally, some of the oldest manuscripts of Matthew read "Joseph begat Jesus" and many current references to Joseph are "Jesus's father" in the oldest manuscripts. The genealogy in Matthew makes no sense if Mary conceived as a virgin, as it shows Joseph's line of descent, not Mary's, and the whole point is to show how Jesus came from the Davidic line. I have a theory however about why this story was added: the faithless church fathers, instead of believing because it is self-evident, either newly interpreted Isaiah 7:14 as messianic, or it was actually put there by Matthew, but the church fathers, due to a mistranslation in the LXX, thought it meant virgin when it was actually young woman (the same word is used for both). Either way, they lacked faith and only cared about creating a religious system to control people, and authored this story to "prove" it right. Ironically, the original Hebrew prophecy is only correct if Joseph is Jesus's (biological) father. It's also possible that they wanted to introduce elements of pagan legends, though harmless ones in this case (unless you take it to the extreme of worshiping Mary).

post.body:
Currently most successful people are men. So are the least. The current consensus is that the average intelligence for both sexes is the same, but males are more variable than females.

I call that bull. I think the entire intelligence curve for females is simply shifted to the right of males. In every single hard class at high school and university level, there are far more boys but the handful of girls are always at the top of the class, easily solving problems that stump the hell out of the boys. It's the same at any non-blue-collar workplace, there are more male employees overall but the female minority does a better job, is more productive, and comes up with more ideas. All across the board it's been shown that girls are substantially better learners than boys, and have sharper and more active minds. Girls also have a *significant* advantage in the arts, languages, music, humanities, even just simple functions like memory and emotion. While still having a slight advantage even in "male" subjects like STEM. Pretty much anything involving designing or creating, even simple outside the box thinking, females are naturally going to be way better. Males commit suicide 3.5x more despite supposedly having less depression (I suspect it's actually because depression is biologically hardwired into males so is rarely taken seriously for them, in fact "whining" about it is usually punished).

It's not just stereotypes and observational evidence though. Brain scans back this up too. Female brains are typically a bit smaller, but so was Einstein's. Female brains have denser neurons that more than make up for it, and their hippocampus and cortices are all larger and wired much more efficiently than in males, which correlates to higher cognitive ability. Not only that, but it's been shown that males pretty much exclusively use the left side of their brain (logical, stoic, rational, logical, and blunt) while females are capable of using both sides. This is why men are usually so uncreative, unemotional (except for anger), unartistic, unsympathetic, and lack even the most basic intuition and feeling. Pretty much the only thing males excel at in the mental realm is spatial awareness. And even then, only in the real physical world; females are still usually superior at crafting, designing, and drawing shapes and 3d perspectives. This also makes biological sense. Think back to ancient times, when male was the more "disposable" sex that was constantly sent into risky and brutal situations, fighting, mating, and laboring, while the females engaged more in homemaking, childrearing, and organizing society. You don't need much of a brain to do the former, and with so many resources devoted to it, males lose a lot of other capabilities. Men are pretty much smarter as children than they are as adults! Why do you think Homer Simpson is so familiar? This explains some other things too, like why men die younger and feel pain worse despite having to endure more painful situations.

So why are some men still more successful and have higher IQs? My theory is societal expectations. From the moment they enter school, boys MUST succeed, do what they're told, and do it *extremely* well or there will be consequences. Girls are usually given a lot more slack. Boys are expected to have careers and become independent, whereas girls are allowed to leech off of them their whole lives, and allowed to run to someone else crying for help with every tiny thing that doesn't go their way. So what happens is that only the ambitious girls end up cultivating their skills. And when they do, the results are amazing. But obviously the people who actually *want* to pursue things instead of being lazy are the minority of the population. If you pick out 10 geniuses, chances are 9 of them will be boys but the one girl will be smarter than half of them combined. She will usually be multi-talented, easy to work with, have a lot of ideas, well-rounded and brilliant. Top IQs reflect this, in which they are almost all males but the #1 spot goes to a female. If most females would put down the makeup and snapchat and become interested in something actually productive like the males are made to do, I think their intelligence would improve quite drastically. But we instead encourage that hyper "girly" behavior which doesn't accomplish anything except make it even harder for the sexes to understand each other than it already would be. Boys are far too neglected and girls are way too coddled. It doesn't make any sense to have lower expectations for the ones with higher potential. I think there needs to be a serious shift in raising girls to become productive persons rather than docile crybabies. They'd be happier and have more fun that way too.

guild.description:
This guild is to serve as a communication medium for fellow believers. The bible is the ultimate source of authority for any and all doctrine or doctrinal disputes. Posts can be made questioning the validity/veracity of the bible itself, but in any conversation wherein the topic itself is not the legitimacy of the bible, then it is assumed to be correct and factual. How else can any foundation be established except if the bible is a source of truth? Is man's opinion above God's word?

To the greatest extent possible i will avoid all forms of censorship, even spam would ideally be dealt with by down-voting rather than deleting. There is no restriction on post-type (you can post whatever you want) aside from the obvious nono's like porn, spam, calls to violence, etc..

post.body:
This is really quite remarkable, it would be interesting if anyone knows Latin if this could be "explained away." Anyway, I saw a post on Gab about this, and verified it myself, taking 4 screenshots, if anyone wants to see the others I'll put them in the comments.

If you want to repeat this for yourself, go to google and type "translate quarantine" into the search, then change the desired language to Latin. Once you've done this, click the double arrows in the middle 3 times, translating back and forth, the attached picture is the final result.

I'm not exactly sure what to make of it, I would almost be inclined to think that the "Jews" purposefully manipulated the process to force this result; a "rub it in their faces" sort of thing if you will. In either case, whether it is a legitimate "coincidence," or purposefully manipulated to have this result, it seems to hint at something bigger behind the scenes of all of the chaos, if you didn't already believe this was the case.

The proceeding passage is usually rendered as "as were some of you" but could also mean "as some of you might be" which is more consistent with the next sentences about it "not being beneficial".

post.body:
John 14:15:

Emphasis added.
>**If ye love me, keep my commandments.** And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you another Comforter, that he may abide with you for ever; even the Spirit of truth; whom the world cannot receive, because it seeth him not, neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you.

>I will not leave you comfortless: I will come to you. Yet a little while, and the world seeth me no more; but ye see me: because I live, ye shall live also. At that day ye shall know that I am in my Father, and ye in me, and I in you.

>**He that hath my commandments, and keepeth them, he it is that loveth me**: and he that loveth me shall be loved of my Father, and I will love him, and will manifest myself to him.

This lines up well with the definition of love as presented in 1 John 3:18:

>My little children, let us not love in word or in tongue, but in deed and in truth.

Love is not spoken, it is acted out. It is helping people, it is being patient with people, it is telling them the truth. The most basic example of loving someone by telling them the truth, is telling them if there is a booger hanging out of their nose rather than letting them go on their day looking foolish. But of course, most boogers are much harder to explain to people, boogers like greed and pride and our sinful nature.

So if love includes telling people the truth, what is *the* truth? Because surely, just convincing someone to eat less, while it helps them, and would better their life, is that a more pressing issue than the fact that there is no hope outside of Christ? Why else do they see food as the solution to all of their problems, rather than the cause of many? What truth transcends truths such as "you have a booger hanging out of your nose," and, "you really should lose some weight?"

>“I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me.

Here is this man Jesus claiming to himself be *the* truth, and not only *the* truth, but *the* way and *the* life; was Jesus puffed up like a marshmallow here? or was he telling the truth soberly? 

He also claims exclusive authority over any and all who desire to come to God, also telling us that if we have seen him, we have seen God, also in John 14:

>Jesus said to him, “Have I been with you so long, and yet you have not known Me, Philip? He who has seen Me has seen the Father; so how can you say, ‘Show us the Father’?

Wow, so at this point, this man is either the most delusional, prideful, and narcissistic person to have ever lived, or he is who he claims to be, surely this is not a slip of the tongue or a matter of semantics.  Did you guys know that there are numerous other people who came both before and after Jesus, claiming to be the messiah? Jesus himself referenced them, Gamliel referenced them, and a quick google search will yield a list of those who have come after him, though the list of those before seems harder to find, likely lost in time.

What distinction can be made between Jesus and these other tens, maybe hundreds of people who claimed to be the Jewish messiah? That all of the others came to nothing; almost as though God not only lifted up Jesus, but also put down all other false messiahs, and brought them to nought, as described by Gamaliel in Acts 5:33:

>When they heard this, they were furious and plotted to kill them. Then one in the council stood up, a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the law held in respect by all the people, and commanded them to put the apostles outside for a little while. 

>And he said to them: “Men of Israel, take heed to yourselves what you intend to do regarding these men. For some time ago Theudas rose up, claiming to be somebody. A number of men, about four hundred, joined him. He was slain, and all who obeyed him were scattered and came to nothing. After this man, Judas of Galilee rose up in the days of the census, and drew away many people after him. He also perished, and all who obeyed him were dispersed. 

>And now I say to you, keep away from these men and let them alone; for if this plan or this work is of men, it will come to nothing; but if it is of God, you cannot overthrow it—lest you even be found to fight against God.”

Here some 2000 years later, and Jesus' prophecy that the gates of Hell shall not prevail against his church still stands true, however weak the body may be after millennia of persecution and tribulation, in Matthew 16:18:

>And I also say to you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build My church, **and the gates of Hades shall not prevail against it.**

So, how is it that all other religions have had such weak ripples, Jewish messiahs specifically have had almost no success, as though they only threw a pebble into a pond, but Jesus has seemingly thrown a mountain into a sea? How could this be? 

Can this be attributed to our "reptile" overlords, as many assert? That religion is a tool to control the population? Did Satan come up with the idea of moral perfection, the pursuit of righteousness, and faith in God, and eternal life, all in an effort to control those very people that he already had control of as he saw fit?

*Can* these concepts be made up? How often do you speak with trouble makers, ungodly folk, and they try to subvert you into behaving perfectly, righteously, and virtuously? Even most "pastors" I speak to do not encourage such behavior. Why? How can the bible be so "popular" but nobody actually takes it seriously? 

Jesus asked (Luke 6:46), why do you call Me ‘Lord, Lord,’ and not do the things which I say?

You might want to think long and hard about whether you really love God or not.  Not just if you want to love him, but if you really love him. If you really recognize him as who he claims to be, the creator of heaven and earth. Imagine claiming to recognize someone as the creator of heaven and earth, but still thinking you know better than him. "I know Jesus said not to do that but it's okay, he will forgive me."  MY FRIEND, have you not received forgiveness already?? Why then should he have to do it again? How long will you grieve his heart? How long will **we** grieve his heart?

Matthew 7:21

>“Not everyone who says to Me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ shall enter the kingdom of heaven, but he who does the will of My Father in heaven. Many will say to Me in that day, ‘Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in Your name, cast out demons in Your name, and done many wonders in Your name?’ And then I will declare to them, **‘I never knew you; depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness!’**

Do you practice lawlessness? Not as in, do you not wear your seatbelt, but as in, are you fornicating? Are you a drunkard? Are you covetous, your life consisting of material possessions? Do you steal? Do you scoff? Do you ignore the needy? Do you turn away the simple?

Know ye not that the unrighteous shall not inherit the kingdom of God? as attested by Paul in 1 Corinthians 6:9:

>Do you not know that the unrighteous will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived. Neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor homosexuals, nor sodomites, nor thieves, nor covetous, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor extortioners will inherit the kingdom of God.

"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
All of the english versions are corrupt, because they are translations, and all translations are based on the interpretation of the translators. In this instance it could either mean were or could be. Most english versions adopt the former because the church, both catholic and protestant, have moved towards more of a works salvation and legalism over time (despite not admitting it, because they still want an excuse to do certain wrongs themselves). The only way 1 Cor. 6:9-10 can be reconciled with Paul's grace theology however, is if he means "might be". Indeed, he follows with "Everything is lawful for me, but not everything is good", etc.

Another possibility is that these verses are part of a non-Pauline interpolation. This would make sense too, because for some reason 1 Corinthians in particular is FULL of pastoral interpolations in attempt to make Paul agree with the fake epistles 1 & 2 Timothy and Titus. Looking at 6:9-10, the parallels between it and 1 Timothy 1:9-11 are obvious, even sharing a few words that are attested *nowhere else in Greek writings*. It appears the writer made them up out of obsession with particular topics, indicating that the writer of 1 Cor 6:9-10 and 1 Timothy are likely the same. And we can be quite certain that the author of the original 1 Corinthians (Paul) is not the person who wrote 1 Timothy. Though it is also possible that the writer of 1 Timothy copied authentic Paul, verses 9-10 strike me as more typical of the pastoral writer than Paul. This section has parts missing in 2 or 3 greek manuscripts, albeit rather late ones (9th century) and most of the redactions were made prior to any significant copying of the epistles, so I wouldn't really call that evidence. This explanation makes the most sense to me, because it *does* seem like verses 9-10 are really trying to push the sinless perfection narrative (it's actually difficult to not translate it as "The unrighteous ones of God will not inherit the kingdom"), even though Paul goes on to say the exact opposite a few verses later, and also did so earlier in the same letter (see 3:15), not to mention everything in his other letters. Another contradiction is that in the very same passage, Paul, or more likely "Paul" commands the Corinthians to judge those in the church, probably implying that they should kill the person in question...when Paul said literally the *exact opposite* earlier on in the letter (4:3-5), as he usually does. However, while there is an off-section in this part of the text, it is only 6:3-6. The rest of it the redactor has bridged quite well to the original text, as I cannot tell exactly where it begins and ends as I usually can, just the parts which contradict real Paul. This fact is evidence that they may be wrongly translated and interpreted instead of interpolated, but I feel like that's a bit of a stretch from the way they're worded. Either way, it's difficult to imagine Paul intending these messages when he always taught the opposite.

And we can be quite certain that the author of the original 1 Corinthians (Paul) is not the person who wrote 1 Timothy. Though it is also possible that the writer of 1 Timothy copied authentic Paul, verses 9-10 strike me as more typical of the pastoral writer than Paul. This section has parts missing in 2 or 3 greek manuscripts, albeit rather late ones (9th century) and most of the redactions were made prior to any significant copying of the epistles, so I wouldn't really call that evidence. This explanation makes the most sense to me, because it does seem like verses 9-10 are really trying to push the sinless perfection narrative (it's actually difficult to not translate it as "The unrighteous ones of God will not inherit the kingdom"), even though Paul goes on to say the exact opposite a few verses later, and also did so earlier in the same letter (see 3:15), not to mention everything in his other letters. Another contradiction is that in the very same passage, Paul, or more likely "Paul" commands the Corinthians to judge those in the church, probably implying that they should kill the person in question...when Paul said literally the exact opposite earlier on in the letter (4:3-5), as he usually does. However, while there is an off-section in this part of the text, it is only 6:3-6. The rest of it the redactor has bridged quite well to the original text, as I cannot tell exactly where it begins and ends as I usually can, just the parts which contradict real Paul. This fact is evidence that they may be wrongly translated and interpreted instead of interpolated, but I feel like that's a bit of a stretch from the way they're worded. Either way, it's difficult to imagine Paul intending these messages when he always taught the opposite.

post.body:
John 14:15:

Emphasis added.
>**If ye love me, keep my commandments.** And I will pray the Father, and he shall give you another Comforter, that he may abide with you for ever; even the Spirit of truth; whom the world cannot receive, because it seeth him not, neither knoweth him: but ye know him; for he dwelleth with you, and shall be in you.

>I will not leave you comfortless: I will come to you. Yet a little while, and the world seeth me no more; but ye see me: because I live, ye shall live also. At that day ye shall know that I am in my Father, and ye in me, and I in you.

>**He that hath my commandments, and keepeth them, he it is that loveth me**: and he that loveth me shall be loved of my Father, and I will love him, and will manifest myself to him.

This lines up well with the definition of love as presented in 1 John 3:18:

>My little children, let us not love in word or in tongue, but in deed and in truth.

Love is not spoken, it is acted out. It is helping people, it is being patient with people, it is telling them the truth. The most basic example of loving someone by telling them the truth, is telling them if there is a booger hanging out of their nose rather than letting them go on their day looking foolish. But of course, most boogers are much harder to explain to people, boogers like greed and pride and our sinful nature.

So if love includes telling people the truth, what is *the* truth? Because surely, just convincing someone to eat less, while it helps them, and would better their life, is that a more pressing issue than the fact that there is no hope outside of Christ? Why else do they see food as the solution to all of their problems, rather than the cause of many? What truth transcends truths such as "you have a booger hanging out of your nose," and, "you really should lose some weight?"

>“I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father except through Me.

Here is this man Jesus claiming to himself be *the* truth, and not only *the* truth, but *the* way and *the* life; was Jesus puffed up like a marshmallow here? or was he telling the truth soberly? 

He also claims exclusive authority over any and all who desire to come to God, also telling us that if we have seen him, we have seen God, also in John 14:

>Jesus said to him, “Have I been with you so long, and yet you have not known Me, Philip? He who has seen Me has seen the Father; so how can you say, ‘Show us the Father’?

Wow, so at this point, this man is either the most delusional, prideful, and narcissistic person to have ever lived, or he is who he claims to be, surely this is not a slip of the tongue or a matter of semantics.  Did you guys know that there are numerous other people who came both before and after Jesus, claiming to be the messiah? Jesus himself referenced them, Gamliel referenced them, and a quick google search will yield a list of those who have come after him, though the list of those before seems harder to find, likely lost in time.

What distinction can be made between Jesus and these other tens, maybe hundreds of people who claimed to be the Jewish messiah? That all of the others came to nothing; almost as though God not only lifted up Jesus, but also put down all other false messiahs, and brought them to nought, as described by Gamaliel in Acts 5:33:

>When they heard this, they were furious and plotted to kill them. Then one in the council stood up, a Pharisee named Gamaliel, a teacher of the law held in respect by all the people, and commanded them to put the apostles outside for a little while. 

>And he said to them: “Men of Israel, take heed to yourselves what you intend to do regarding these men. For some time ago Theudas rose up, claiming to be somebody. A number of men, about four hundred, joined him. He was slain, and all who obeyed him were scattered and came to nothing. After this man, Judas of Galilee rose up in the days of the census, and drew away many people after him. He also perished, and all who obeyed him were dispersed. 

>And now I say to you, keep away from these men and let them alone; for if this plan or this work is of men, it will come to nothing; but if it is of God, you cannot overthrow it—lest you even be found to fight against God.”

Here some 2000 years later, and Jesus' prophecy that the gates of Hell shall not prevail against his church still stands true, however weak the body may be after millennia of persecution and tribulation, in Matthew 16:18:

>And I also say to you that you are Peter, and on this rock I will build My church, **and the gates of Hades shall not prevail against it.**

So, how is it that all other religions have had such weak ripples, Jewish messiahs specifically have had almost no success, as though they only threw a pebble into a pond, but Jesus has seemingly thrown a mountain into a sea? How could this be? 

Can this be attributed to our "reptile" overlords, as many assert? That religion is a tool to control the population? Did Satan come up with the idea of moral perfection, the pursuit of righteousness, and faith in God, and eternal life, all in an effort to control those very people that he already had control of as he saw fit?

*Can* these concepts be made up? How often do you speak with trouble makers, ungodly folk, and they try to subvert you into behaving perfectly, righteously, and virtuously? Even most "pastors" I speak to do not encourage such behavior. Why? How can the bible be so "popular" but nobody actually takes it seriously? 

Jesus asked (Luke 6:46), why do you call Me ‘Lord, Lord,’ and not do the things which I say?

You might want to think long and hard about whether you really love God or not.  Not just if you want to love him, but if you really love him. If you really recognize him as who he claims to be, the creator of heaven and earth. Imagine claiming to recognize someone as the creator of heaven and earth, but still thinking you know better than him. "I know Jesus said not to do that but it's okay, he will forgive me."  MY FRIEND, have you not received forgiveness already?? Why then should he have to do it again? How long will you grieve his heart? How long will **we** grieve his heart?

Matthew 7:21

>“Not everyone who says to Me, ‘Lord, Lord,’ shall enter the kingdom of heaven, but he who does the will of My Father in heaven. Many will say to Me in that day, ‘Lord, Lord, have we not prophesied in Your name, cast out demons in Your name, and done many wonders in Your name?’ And then I will declare to them, **‘I never knew you; depart from Me, you who practice lawlessness!’**

Do you practice lawlessness? Not as in, do you not wear your seatbelt, but as in, are you fornicating? Are you a drunkard? Are you covetous, your life consisting of material possessions? Do you steal? Do you scoff? Do you ignore the needy? Do you turn away the simple?

Know ye not that the unrighteous shall not inherit the kingdom of God? as attested by Paul in 1 Corinthians 6:9:

>Do you not know that the unrighteous will not inherit the kingdom of God? Do not be deceived. Neither fornicators, nor idolaters, nor adulterers, nor homosexuals, nor sodomites, nor thieves, nor covetous, nor drunkards, nor revilers, nor extortioners will inherit the kingdom of God.

This is really quite remarkable, it would be interesting if anyone knows Latin if this could be "explained away." Anyway, I saw a post on Gab about this, and verified it myself, taking 4 screenshots, if anyone wants to see the others I'll put them in the comments.

If you want to repeat this for yourself, go to google and type "translate quarantine" into the search, then change the desired language to Latin. Once you've done this, click the double arrows in the middle 3 times, translating back and forth, the attached picture is the final result.

I'm not exactly sure what to make of it, I would almost be inclined to think that the "Jews" purposefully manipulated the process to force this result; a "rub it in their faces" sort of thing if you will. In either case, whether it is a legitimate "coincidence," or purposefully manipulated to have this result, it seems to hint at something bigger behind the scenes of all of the chaos, if you didn't already believe this was the case.

This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. For God did not send the Son into the world to judge the world, but that the world might be saved through Him. He who believes in Him is not judged; he who does not believe has been judged already, because he has not believed in the name of the only begotten Son of God. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God.

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:
Let's pretend evil is required to have free will: You made men capable of evil, then punish them for being evil by sentencing them to a (virtually) eternal pyre. Why? There can be but one reason: You(Their Creator) is malignant.

Evil only makes sense in the world we live in if there is no God, God is apathetic, or if God is also evil. All three incompatible with Monotheistic faith. There are no non-paradoxical alternatives.

You've answered this paradox, but only because the paradox fails to account for something (conveniently) extremely obvious.

"His house, his rules." is tyrannical.
